Comment: My typical questionable move, that provides a square for the bishop to retire, supports an early g4, which denies f5 to the black's dsb... if e3, Nh4 and my dsb will be exchanged. It is not a catastrophe, but I don't like it.

The typical c4 allows black counterplay on the diagonal. I want to solid block the queenside and attack on the kingside. I'm a little "naive" here, since black can calmly develop and wait. A queenside castling could be advisable later.

No bf4. Plus, a pawn's storm project on the kingside.
No bf4. Plus, a pawn's storm project on the kingside.
Losing flexibility. c5 is a move black should have in mind all the time, specially if he wants to castle kingside disregarding the white clouds approaching.
In order to advance g5, I have to make impossible for the knight to go to h4.
Black seems to be ok, but in fact he is not. Black's lsb has just d7, and the queen cannot move.
Now, no Nh4. It can go to e, but I have to accept it.
Preparing a break on e5, of course.
This allows Bf5, but I want to attack.
Despite its prominency, this knight is not all that strong here, unless black manages to sac it. But he has no play on the dark squares...
Helping e5.
Good, black has not a plan. As you can see, this move doesn't solve anything to black.
Thinking on h5, of course. But it has the offside that allows...
Nb-d2 was ok, but I wanted to manage the situation in another way.
...but in the meanwhile, I forgot about the e5 push blacks were preparing. And now, this is really dangerous, since I have a rook in front my queen and king.
